Description: Egyptian terracotta figure head of a bald man. A head of a male grotesque, broken from a figure. He may be a priest, and has an elongated bald head, prominent lips and large ears; the neck is comparatively thin. Solid, from two-piece mould. White dressing (probably gypsum), painted over with pink and details subsequently added in black, around the eyes and red by the ears. Brown Nile silt with abundant fine gold mica and white inclusions.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), Probably from the city (Bailey 2008: 151), town or Aphrodite sanctuary. (?)
Curator's comments: Described as Hellenistic in original publication (Gardner and Griffith 1888, pl. 15, no. 3).
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (C622)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.519) (Phase 1)
